We will consider a very basic example neglecting effects like molecular crowding or the influence of chaperons on the refolding process. Protein refolding is a multi step process which can be described as outlined below: In [6]: from IPython.display import Image Image ( './images/folding.png' , width = 400 , height = 400 ) Out[6]: Ideally, the unfolded protein collapses into a partially folded state and folds completely into the native state. However, several unwanted side reactions can occur: the proteins can form aggregates with each other or partially folded protein can misfold. The collapse into partially folded protein is usually very fast. Therefore we will consider only the folding step into native protein. An the simplest case, this reaction can be described by a first order model: $$ \frac{dC_{folded}}{dt} = k_{fold} \, C_{unfolded}$$ where $C_{unfolded}$ denotes the concentration of unfolded proteins, t denotes time and $k_{fold}$ the first order rate constant. In the simplest case, protein aggregation happens during the collision of two protein molecules. It is not that simple because aggregates themselves can undergo aggregation with unfolded protein and other aggregated proteins. But lets stick to the simplest case for now, which is a second order reaction: $$ \frac{dC_{agg}}{dt} = k_{agg} \, C_{unfolded}^2$$ We now have to connect everything together with a mass balance. In our simple case the total protein concentration has to stay constant. Under the assumption that the volume stays the same, we can write: $$\frac{dC_{unfolded}}{dt} = - \frac{dC_{folded}}{dt} - \frac{dC_{agg}}{dt} $$ Implementation in python For convenience we will use the odeint interface. First, lets define our system of equations: In [13]: from scipy.integrate import odeint import numpy as np from matplotlib import pyplot as plt % matplotlib inline plt . style . use ( 'seaborn-muted' ) In [110]: def ode_refold ( c , t , k_fold , k_agg ): # lets create an array with length of 3 (folded, aggregated, unfolded) dcdt = np . zeros ( 3 ) # folded dcdt [ 0 ] = k_fold * c [ 2 ] # aggregated dcdt [ 1 ] = k_agg * c [ 2 ] ** 2 # unfolded (has to be defined at last because we have to define dcdt[0] and dcdt[1] firs) dcdt [ 2 ] = - dcdt [ 0 ] - dcdt [ 1 ] return dcdt Lets create the initial conditions and solve the system In [140]: c_unfolded = 10 # mg/L c_foldet = 0 # mol/L c_agg = 0 # mol/L M = 30000 # Molar mass in Da # the order is important. It has to match our definition in ode_refold(..) c0 = [ c_foldet , c_agg , c_unfolded / M ] # now lets create a second set of starting conditions with lower initial concentration c1 = [ c_foldet , c_agg , c_unfolded / 10 / M ] # the rate constants k_fold = 1e-4 # 1/s k_agg = 3e-1 # 1/s # create a vector of timepoints to solve on t = np . linspace ( 0 , 4e4 , 100 ) # solve for the case of high initial protein concentration sol = odeint ( ode_refold , c0 , t , args = ( k_fold , k_agg )) # solve for lower initial protein concentration sol1 = odeint ( ode_refold , c1 , t , args = ( k_fold , k_agg )) # plot the solutions side by side with the suplots function fig , ax = plt . subplots ( ncols = 2 , figsize = ( 10 , 5 )) # plot the solution at high initial protein concentratio ax [ 0 ] . plot ( t , sol [:, 0 ] * M , label = 'folded' ) ax [ 0 ] . plot ( t , sol [:, 1 ] * M , label = 'aggregated' ) ax [ 0 ] . plot ( t , sol [:, 2 ] * M , label = 'unfolded' ) ax [ 0 ] . legend ( loc = 'best' ) # the syntax with ax. is slightly different than with plt. ax [ 0 ] . set_title ( 'Initial concentration: {:0.1f} mg/mL' . format ( c0 [ - 1 ] * M )) ax [ 0 ] . set_ylabel ( 'Concentration (mg/mL)' ) ax [ 0 ] . set_xlabel ( 'Time (sec)' ) # plot the solution at high initial protein concentratio ax [ 1 ] . plot ( t , sol1 [:, 0 ] * M , label = 'folded' ) ax [ 1 ] . plot ( t , sol1 [:, 1 ] * M , label = 'aggregated' ) ax [ 1 ] . plot ( t , sol1 [:, 2 ] * M , label = 'unfolded' ) ax [ 1 ] . legend ( loc = 'best' ) # the syntax with ax. is slightly different than with plt. ax [ 1 ] . set_title ( 'Initial concentration: {:0.1f} mg/mL' . format ( c1 [ - 1 ] * M )) #ax[1].set_ylabel('Concentration (mg/mL)') ax [ 1 ] . set_xlabel ( 'Time (sec)' ) Out[140]: Text(0.5,0,'Time (sec)') The example above is purely theoretical but it highlights nicely why protein refolding usually requires large tank volumes. Typically, aggregation follows a second order kinetic, the rate of reaction is much more dependent on the initial protein concentration than the folding reaction. As a result, the yield of native protein decreases with increasing initial protein concentration. Non constant rate constants As mentioned before, proteins undergo folding only under suitable conditions. Typically, native proteins are prepared by dissolution of so called inclusion bodies . Typically, these inclusion bodies are dissolved under high urea (or other chaotropic agents) concentrations. } .ansi-white-intense-bg { background-color: #A1A6B2; } .ansi-bold { font-weight: bold; } Diffusion in 1D with python This notebook is inspired by the chapter "Cells and Diffusion" in the book Physiochemical and Environmental Plant Physiology . We will walk through a very simple example of 1 dimensional diffusion across a membrane and how to solve the differential equation numerically with python. We will be using ode from scipy integrate package. If you are not familiar with python and the packages I use, get python from anaconda and follow a tutorial like the scipy lecture notes Some theory Diffusion across a thin membrane can be described by the well known Fick's 1th law: $$ \label{fick_1} J_j = - D_j \, \frac{\partial c_j}{\partial x}$$ The flux density $J_j$ is proportional to the diffusion coefficient $D_j$ of species $j$ and the concentration gradient $\frac{\partial c_j}{\partial x}$ in direction x. The flux density is given in in $mol \, m^{-2} \, s^{-1}$ and the diffusion coefficient in in $mol \, m^{-2} \, s^{-1}$. The image below highlights the point, that we do consider diffusion only along one direction. By convention, a net flow in the direction of increasing x is positive. The minus sign in the equation is needed because flow occurs only towards region with lower concentration ($\partial c_j$ is negative if the concentration on the right side is lower). In [2]: # For displaying images from IPython.display import Image Image ( 'images/1d_diffusion.png' , width = 200 , height = 200 ) Out[2]: We could ask ourself the question how the concentration of a substance evolves over time would evolve if we place a drop if ink on the left side of the membrane shown above. Currently, we have a relationship between the flux across a membrane and the axial direction: $$ J_j = - D_j \, \frac{\partial c_j}{\partial x}$$ There is no time there. What to do ? We can follow the explanations on page 15 of the book Physiochemical and Environmental Plant Physiology (I am tired and lazy right now) and use the continuum equation $$ \frac{\partial c_j}{\partial t} = -\frac{\partial J_j}{\partial x} $$ The equation states that the change of concentration over time for component $j$ is proportional to the change of the flux density over x. If we plug the equation equation \ref{fick_1}, we obtain Fick's second law: $$ \label{fick_2} \frac{\partial c_j}{\partial t} = \frac{\partial}{\partial x} \left( -\frac{\partial J_j}{\partial x} \right) = -\frac{\partial^2 J_j}{\partial x^2}$$ If there is no obstruction between $x$ and $x+dx$ and the solute is placed at position 0, it is possible to derive an analytical expression for equation \ref{fick_2}. However, we would like to consider the diffusion across a membrane: In [3]: Image ( './images/1d_diffusion_membrane.png' , height = 250 , width = 250 ) Out[3]: If we neglect the boundary layers (between dashed lines) and discretize $\frac{\partial c_j}{\partial x}$ we can express equation \ref{fick_1} as: $$\label{flux_K} J_j = D_j \, \frac{K_j \, (c_j^i - c_j^0)}{\Delta x} = P_j \, \frac{(c_j^i - c_j^0)}{\Delta x}$$ Because $D_j$ is the diffusion coefficient inside the membrane, we have to take the solubility $K_j$ of species $j$ inside the membrane into account. In order to make life simpler, we can define the Permeability $P_j = D_j \, K_j / \Delta x$ and arrive at following equation: $$\label{flux_P} J_j = P_j \, (c_j^i - c_j^0)$$ The permeability has the units $m \, s^{-1}$ Let $s_j$ be the amount (in moles) of substance $j$ inside the cell. If we consider that the flux density is is the rate of entry of substance per unit area, we can write: $$\frac{ds_j}{dt} = J_j \,A = P_j \, A \, (c_j^i - c_j^0)$$ Because $s_j = c_j \, V$ and the Volume (V) inside the cell is nearly constant, we can write: $$\label{1d_final}\frac{dc_j}{dt} = J_j \,A = \frac{P_j \, A}{V} \, (c_j^i - c_j^0)$$ We will use equation \ref{1d_final} for our calculations Time to get the hands dirty There several convenient packages for solving differential equations: odeint : a simple interface to the FORTRAN library odepack. In many cases this is a good choice due to the simplicity of the interface. Watch out ode : A generic interface to a couple of integrators. It is not as convenient as odeint but you can switch more easily between different integrators. Especially, lsoda might be interesting because odepack does not handle stiff systems well. assimulo : a wrapper to a wide variety of solvers. Especially, if you would like to solve differential algebraic equations, assimulo might be very useful. We will use the ode and odeint interface for comparison.
